awd_abstract_narration:
Modern biology is in the midst of profound change, owing in part to the convergence of ideas from the mathematical sciences with those in the biological and life sciences.  It is a national goal to accelerate this convergence and it is the role of the Mathematical Biosciences Institute (MBI) to help with this acceleration.  Common principles in mathematics, statistics, and computational science are helping scientific understanding in fields as diverse as neuroscience, epidemiology, ecology, genomics, physiology, and cancer, among many others.  MBI supports these interactions through robust postdoctoral fellow and early career research and training programs and through a workshop program that brings together interdisciplinary researchers in the mathematical and life sciences.

MBI has four principal goals.  (1) To foster innovation in the application of mathematical, statistical, and computational methods in the resolution of significant problems in the biosciences.  (2) To foster the development of new areas in the mathematical sciences motivated by important questions in the biosciences.  (3) To engage mathematical and biological scientists in these pursuits.  (4) To expand the community of scholars in mathematical biosciences through education, training, and support of students, postdoctoral fellows, and researchers.   MBI will achieve these goals through its extensive and distributed postdoctoral fellow program based on co-mentoring by researchers in both the mathematical and biological sciences; through its early career training program that enables tenure-track but untenured researchers to participate in MBI programming for an extended period; through its robust interdisciplinary workshop programs; and through its long-term visitor program.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The Mathematical Biosciences Institute (MBI) was established in 2002 on the campus of The Ohio State University, with a five-year NSF award. The grant was renewed at five-year intervals until 2015, when MBI received a reduced, three-year award. This was the fourth and final award to MBI.

 In 2002, it was recognized that mathematical biology including applications to medicine would become a major branch of mathematics although most mathematics departments and individual mathematicians had little knowledge or understanding of the field and its possibilities.  What was needed was to connect mathematics departments and mathematicians to these new opportunities. The MBI was conceived as the vehicle for this change. Thus, the MBI?s mission was not to conduct research but to develop programs that would make these connections. The MBI did this through two major programs, the Workshop Program and the Postdoc Program. Throughout its operation, MBI has maintained a high standard for diversity among postdocs, workshop speakers and participants and visitors.

In the Workshop Program, the MBI organized twelve weeklong workshops each year on a wide range of topics, some with biological or medical themes, some with mathematical themes, but all of them focusing on how mathematics can be used to solve biological and medical problems. Each workshop was organized by a group of experts (both biological and mathematical) in the field, mostly non-OSU faculty members. Faculty, postdocs, and graduate students from all over the world visited the MBI for these workshops. The pandemic arrived during the No Cost Extension period of the award, forcing workshops online and reducing their number.

In the Postdoc program, the MBI usually hired 3-4 postdocs each year for three-year terms, so there was typically a community of 10 postdocs in residence, though the number was sometimes larger. The postdocs had both math and biology mentors and received professional development training. More than 75 postdocs (20 at MBI during this award period) trained at MBI now hold academic positions at American or international universities though some have taken jobs in medical centers or industry. 

Between 2002 and 2012, the field of mathematical biology grew from a very small and mostly ignored branch of mathematics into a major branch of mathematics. For example, the number of mathematics Ph.D. students saying that their field was mathematical biology grew from almost zero to over 10%, most mathematics departments were trying to hire mathematical biologists, and mathematical biology was recognized as a major branch of applied mathematics. Of course, the MBI cannot claim all the credit for this major sea change, but this sea change was the mission of the MBI and it succeeded. In a way, it succeeded so well that its programs were no longer needed: the connections had been made.   MBI is currently a virtual institute, maintaining a website (https://mbi.osu.edu/) with information, publications, and videos of past events. Its capstone event will be to serve as organizing host for the 50th anniversary meeting of the Society for Mathematical Biology during July 2023 on the OSU campus.

 


Last Modified: 08/03/2022
Modified by: Janet A Best
